page.title: 06ELIZABETH CASTLE,ST.HELIER
page.content: The castle is a tourist attraction which is floodlit at night. Situated on an islet about half a mile out at sea from St.Helier it can be reached by a causeway which uncovers at low tide or by amphibious vehicle. At the landward end of a breakwater is the Hermitage Rock where, in the 6th century, the hermit Helier was beheaded by raiding pirates. St.Helier is named after him and the Parish crest is crossed axes in his memory. Queen Elizabeth I ordered the castle built, but it was modified by the addition of German gun emplacements and searchlights during World War II. The castle offers splendid views of St.Helier and St.Aubin's Bay and houses a cafe and a museum which depicts its history which includes its siege during the Civil War.
